But in this Chamber, we also know that history is an implacable judge and that it often retains weaknesses and betrayal, and I hope... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which If the crisis has shown anything, it is that the EU is not a crisis manager. After all, it became clear to everyone that the risk areas were local, and that was where the Länder and the counties were called for. In the end, they also managed the crisis well with great solidarity aid – across borders.  But now you want to eliminate the full consequences of the crisis at EU level with huge aid money. Then the desires grow into heaven. For example, some members here want to increase countries' payment obligations not only by 30%, but even by 100% of the GNI. But that can never be the solution, because that would automatically lead to more debt. And that puts a lot, much more strain on our children's accounts. That is a problem. Mrs von der Leyen spoke of this.  If you really want to deposit into our children's account, avoid Euro bonds and do everything possible to make sure that our children can go back to school.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are at the beginning of the biggest economic crisis since the Second World War. Millions of European women fear for their existence. They lose their jobs, slip into poverty or get sick. Corona doesn't hit everyone the same. The weakest are harder hit than the strong and southern Europe harder than northern Europe.  But if the EU splits on this crisis, we will all lose and all will become weaker. That is why we must act boldly now, and it is good that we are showing this here in Parliament and that we will adopt a strong resolution by a large majority.  We are calling for a 2 trillion plan. We must not repeat the mistakes of the euro crisis. We need more investment and not austerity. Instead of privatisation, we need to invest in our health system, and instead of money for climate polluters, we need climate-friendly infrastructure. And we need an EU budget that will become structurally stronger.  That is why I appeal to Mrs von der Leyen: do not find a solution where more money is available for two years and everything is then cut back. That is not how we are going to fight the crisis. Now it's up to you.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Paradoxically, the drama of a pandemic can really help to think about how to fix the European Union. We have a great opportunity to combat tax fraud within the European Union. Poland does it great and hence has new money. We should eliminate disparities in national state aid. There is also a great deal of work to be done here, because this inequality is simply spoiling the internal market. We need to move away from unnecessary rebates and tax havens. There is potential, new money, new opportunities that the whole of Europe is waiting for.  We can also provide european Union grants and loans through appropriate action, but we must remember that the cohesion of the Union, the common agricultural policy, aid to transport workers, aid to small and medium-sized enterprises will be the basis for the SUCCESS and economic recovery of the EU.

name: Elena KOUNTOURA
text: Mr President, seventy years ago Schuman said that Europe will not be created at once or in an overall edifice. It will be shaped through concrete achievements that will first create real solidarity. His words, then, are more timely than ever today. We are at a critical crossroads and we must choose the path of solidarity, because we risk losing what we have built over the last seventy years. What we are experiencing today in Europe is national interests, national enforcement, not by war but by economic force, the law of absolute over-the-top power. An end must be put to an end and our response to this crisis must be a brave recovery plan. Real support for those who need it with subsidies and not with new debts. New tools for the European Union's own resources, so that the richest do not decide for everyone else. Finally, real democracy with equal participation of the European Parliament in decision-making on the recovery plan.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recovery fund will be essential for recovery. This fund must be able to issue securities, finance itself on the markets and count on at least EUR 1 500 billion or EUR 2 000 billion, but above all it must work by helping European companies non-refundable, not only by issuing loans. The European budget must be used to guarantee and support the fund, as well as European taxes on finance and large corporations, but agreement must be reached so that the fund can be activated immediately, without waiting for lengthy negotiations. The union's seven-year budget should also be amended to reflect the new situation. We propose to add a "Covid impact index" to the criteria for allocating European funds, a tool to be used to temporarily increase European funds to the most affected areas. Still using this indicator, we would like european cofinancing rates to be able to increase to 90 95 %, where necessary. Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, the history of Europe teaches us that every crisis can become an opportunity, if properly managed. Today, seventy years after the Schuman Declaration, we have the opportunity, the burden and, above all, the honour of formulating an unprecedented response for all our citizens, in a word of uniting Europe. Let's show the world what we can all do together!

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has Corona and the consequences of Corona are a historic challenge, which must also be targeted by the multiannual new budget and reconstruction.  I would like to make three comments on this. Firstly, we must not lose sight of the future of Corona because of the crisis. Priorities such as investment in research, digitalisation and innovation-based implementation of the Green Deal must play a very special role in the new budget, despite or precisely because of Corona.  Secondly, it must be ensured that a reconstruction fund that will be closely linked to the new budget is not used by the Member States to plug budget holes. The funds must be used to stimulate the economy and public life, and that must be ensured.  Thirdly, in order to ensure all this, we need, on the one hand, transparency, and we need a democratic say in the use of funds by this House.  I understand the impulse to act quickly in a crisis situation and to make decisions as flexible as possible. However, I think it is particularly important in this situation that the sums that are in the room should be accompanied by parliamentary, democratic codecision and appropriate monitoring on how the funds are used.  I therefore call on the Commission and the Council to take account of the European Parliament's ability to have a say and influence.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, the European Commission should have submitted on 6 May a proposal to renew the multiannual financial framework and to offer this House a powerful Recovery Fund. The Commission did not do so and is presented today with a few notes, while some say that we will not have a formal proposal until the end of the month.  I would like to convey to the Commission that this is clearly unacceptable. And unacceptablely, this Parliament has come together in a resolution which will have almost unanimous support, demanding a rapid response, a solidarity response and a European response to this crisis. That it provides, that it should design a recovery strategy of at least two trillion euros, with a fund financed by Community debt, and that it be channeled to the real economy through, in essence, direct transfers.  And this Parliament also says - and I would like to point it out - that the Commission should refrain from presenting us with a proposal full of phantom multipliers, because this detracts from a lot of credibility not only to the Commission, but to the whole European project.  Finally, I would like to ask the Commission not to wait for the Council to offer a proposal to this House, and that the United Parliament reaches out to the Commission to negotiate together with the Council afterwards. Let's get back to the best ways to work from the last legislature.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, I have to tell you that after the intervention of Ms von der Leyen, I see only business as usual, and I hope that I’m wrong. But I have also seen the first documents circulating in the Commission – and it’s business as usual: it’s old tricks, it’s repackaging, massive frontloading, and then a multiplier – I have seen that the Commission will use a multiplier of 45! Even Jesus in the New Testament was not capable of doing that: a multiplier of 45 when he multiplied the fishes and the bread. But the Commission is on that track, and that’s not, I think, even the opinion just of the Commissioners. That’s typical, in bureaucracy, of how it works. Ms von der Leyen explained today how they are going to do it: they are going to increase the headroom a little bit and ask more guarantees of the Member States. Well they should not think about doing that. All our Member States will be in deficit. All our Member States will be in debt. You cannot increase the national contributions of the Member States by asking for more guarantees in the future. What we need to do is create a new headroom, and a new headroom that is new own resources. That is not an invention. The financing of the European Union was always based on own resources, on VAT, on customs duties, and what we propose now is a digital tax and other taxes against pollution. It is because of the rebate we gave to Margaret Thatcher that in the 1980s we started to stop with these normal democratic finances and that we started to ask for contributions from Member States. Well it’s a good moment to stop that, definitely, and to create real financing for this Union. So the problem is not so much, Mr President, where we are going to spend this – in politics that’s easy. The most important problem is how we are going to fund it. I ask the Commission – Mr Šefčovič, tomorrow in your meeting – to ask for new solutions as we have described here in this resolution.

name: Antonio Maria RINALDI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, of the formidable volume of fire proclaimed in words by the European Union to counter the economic effects of the pandemic, the only mouse that has so far managed to give birth to the elephant has been the ESA: extremely insufficient in size (2 % of the applicant's GDP), limited for the only health destination used and in any case penalising for the continuation of the early warning system in the Memorandum of the Eurogroup of 8 May last. And the much-vaunted recovery fund? To date, nothing is known, is it just funding or even non-grant quotas? Will the guarantees come from the Eu ropean Union budget, which is stuck at 1.07 % of GDP, or from substantial additional percentage contributions from the Member States? On 29 April, the Vice-President of the Commission, Mrs Jourová, stated that 1 January 2021 is a very ambitious date to see it operational. Will the recovery fund also adopt the leverage method proposed by Juncker in 2014 for his famous €300 billion plan that never came to light? The recovery fund will eventually be a bad copy of the EMS in technicalities and conditionalities. While we are discussing the financial instruments to be adopted and wasting valuable time postponing decisions, european companies and, above all, european citizens are on their knees. We are in a situation comparable to a war, but we are still trying to find the right instruments in the treaties and regulations conceived in peacetime. Before we walk through the rubble of a collapsing economy, have the courage and the strength to adopt exceptional and decisive instruments, such as direct intervention by the ECB.  It's time to act, not postpone!

name: David CORMAND
text: "Dear friends, as you know, we know that the budget issue is never a purely accounting issue. It is above all political. But in times of crisis, the budgetary issue becomes even more the question that determines all the others. In the face of the pandemic, Europe's political impotence has a name. It is the lack of own resources that binds our hands together. Not being masters of our recipes, we are not masters of our actions. No member of this house should consent to such democratic dispossession. Europe cannot remain a fiscal and fiscal dwarf. It is imperative that we have our own resources, that is, in reality, arm ourselves politically to face the challenges of the climate emergency, the social crisis and the necessary transformation of our economy. We need our own resources to finance a reconstruction plan, such as restoring fiscal justice, including taxing financial transactions and carbon emissions. Is the European Union intended to exist on the world stage by equipping itself with the means to finance a just and united transition? Without its own resources, the answer will remain no.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, it is clear to all that the Chinese virus crisis will have to restructure the Multiannual Financial Framework, but my opinion and my group's view is that this restructuring should not come at the taxpayer's expense.  I see a lot of unreasonable ideas – raising taxes, new taxes, new taxes, new bureaucracy. No, the answer must be exactly the opposite, Commissioner, and it is precisely the answer that must be in cutting red tape at both the European and national levels.  We are seeing many unreasonable proposals, demands for green deals, for the mobility package, all initiatives that will destroy hundreds of thousands of jobs in Central and Eastern Europe. In fact, the Green Deal directly works for Chinese interest, deindustrialising Europe and moving production to China, and that should be exactly the opposite process we need to pursue at the moment. As much as possible, citizens should be relieved and work to support small and medium-sized businesses, not for unreasonable and foolish ideas such as the Green Deal.  In conclusion, I do not see why you are ashamed to hold China accountable and accountable for the spread of this pandemic.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Mr President, there is going to be money, there will be investments, there will be arrangements. But at the end of the ride, someone's going to have to pay. We need to pay a little more attention to that. But I have some good news. I have found money in Europe and we will not even have to ask the German worker to pay for the Italian billionaire, who will then hide his money in tax haven The Netherlands. No, I went to check out the Forbes list of the super-rich. Bernard Arnault of Louis Vuitton is worth 70 billion euros. He doesn't know what to do with it anymore. Amancio Ortega of the Zara stores is worth 50 billion euros. I don't know, what could we do with it? Or Heinz Hermann Thiele, the billionaire and shareholder of Lufthansa who wants to put countless people on the streets of Belgium today, is worth 10 billion euros. Ladies and gentlemen, the money is there. Let's make those people pay with a corona tax on the wealth of the super-rich. The billionaires will not feel it and it will make a big difference to the workers in Europe. What are we waiting for?

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Mr President, the crisis has blown up the debate on the multiannual financial perspective, as we were just a few months ago. The European Commission's budget will no longer be just the budget of the European Commission, it will also be the resources on which, ultimately, the reconstruction fund and the European bonds that have to finance this fund will be supported. As a result, this budget should make a giant leap to at least 2% of European GDP. The typical and strenuous debates as to whether the Commission's budget had to be a little above or a little below 1% have been ridiculously pulverized by the circumstances, and this leads to an even greater debate. How could the Commission have a budget of this magnitude without new own resources, other than the current ones?  It has been repeated by many Members in the Chamber today. Isn't it time to boost your own taxes? Not only own taxes in the context of own resources, beyond customs duties and the VAT rate; taxes consistent with the new European Green Pact, taxes that help us reduce inequalities, effectively, or perhaps raising at European level some taxes that already operate today at state level in some countries.  The coronavirus crisis has therefore widened the door to a debate so far too silenced: the need to build a true European tax system.  This Parliament must lead this debate. The European Council will not. It's now or never.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The next MED plays a key role in boosting our economies after the crisis and is therefore necessary to be ambitious and of sufficient size. However, given the seriousness of the crisis, a recovery fund envisaged by the Commission is also necessary, but it should not come at the expense of traditional EU policies, which have already proved their usefulness on a number of occasions. Cohesion policy and agricultural policy should therefore also be strengthened. Cohesion policy is the EU's most important investment instrument, of which all States and Member States are winners. Let us preserve the recently introduced flexibility in the use of cohesion funds, at least in the first years of the new MFF. As a Hungarian Member, I will pay particular attention to the fair distribution of funds. Hungary has performed outstandingly in economic catch-up in recent years, with growth of around 5 percent. We are now also at the forefront of tresmanising the epidemic, mobilising the third largest number of resources proportionately, creating a new one to replace all lost jobs. I hope that this great work will not be disadvantaged at EU level. I ask that there will be no moral risk in allocating resources, that neither the MFF nor the recovery fund reward irresponsible management or mismanagement of the epidemic. The aim should be to provide assistance according to the needs and merits of all Member States.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, after the lockdown, go back out. And what's the best way out? There are three choices to be made for this. First, a recovery for all. The euro crisis shows that a problem for one country is a problem for all countries. So don't move problems forward. It is now time for joint loans and mutual support, so that every country can get out of the crisis. That is why Parliament's resolution is so good. Secondly, a sustainable recovery in which people and the environment do not come first. So let us ens state in legislation that no investment from the recovery fund should harm people or the environment. And third, the strongest shoulders, the heaviest loads. This calls for an end to tax avoidance, including within the European Union. This also requires an internal market contribution from the largest companies, a contribution to the European Union's own resources. Those are three choices for the best way out.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is important that we send a common European response in this crisis. That is why it is important that we have a strong MFF and a reconstruction fund – and, incidentally, that we ensure that the MFF is really strengthened and that the programmes with European added value actually remain strengthened and that not everything goes into the reconstruction fund.  But we also need to talk about it: how is this money actually spent? We now have huge sums of money. But where is that supposed to go? I think that we see in this crisis how much digitalisation helps us, how much it is now also making us stronger, and that is why a huge impetus should go into digitisation so that we can actually get out of this crisis more competitively.  But I don't think new taxes will help us. It is precisely in this crisis that this is poison for the European economy. Even a digital tax will only mean that Americans, who will respond to the tariff-mad Trump, will also begin to destroy world trade on the spot. That will not lead us out of the crisis, ladies and gentlemen.  It must be clear that we need a budget that clearly invests in the future. We need a budget that actually gives money only to those in Europe who respect the rule of law.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Mr President, April 2020 was the month of tears: Europe was united by death. In Lombardy as in Belgium, in Spain as in Alsace, Europeans spoke with one voice: indeed, they all wept. Meanwhile, they were waiting for the voice of Europe. On 24 April, the Council concluded through Charles Michel, and I quote: 'we welcomed the common roadmap for recovery'. A statement that may seem indecent when, everywhere, unemployment, poverty and extreme poverty are on the agenda, without a serious recovery plan. EUR 500 billion for the recovery is four times less than in the United States, but it is above all, at this time, no clarification, as the speakers before me have developed: we are still waiting for the Clear Programme of the Commission. What is this roadmap? Special funds with their administration and bureaucracy. We have no doubt that some will have their usefulness but the method will always sin. She will sin because she makes up funds redirected into new funds. It will sin, because it will never have the necessary flexibility. It will sin because it will have been thought of by the same minds that have locked the European Union in this technocracy.

name: Henrike HAHN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Reconstruction after the Corona crisis is not about stivatingly shoveling money into old structures – neither in the Corona crisis nor in the climate crisis.  It's about being smart and prudent. We need a strong MFF and a strong reconstruction plan that shows us how this can be done. We need the Green Deal as a foundation. We are just seeing how vulnerable our way of doing business is.  Now we are not only talking about large car companies and airlines, but also about the many small and medium-sized enterprises. Now it is time to seize this moment and focus on the circular economy, energy and resource efficiency. We need an industrial strategy that implements decarbonisation and climate-neutral economies, which thinks socially about how the people on the ground are doing with it, as in the case of the Fund for a Fair Transition.  We now have a great opportunity to set the right conditions and incentives for a strong, sustainable, competitive economy in Europe. And then we make the most of the crisis.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In my speech, I would like to raise four points. Firstly, I would like to stress very strongly that cohesion policy must continue to be pursued in its current dimension, because it is the most effective way of levelling the level of development between countries and regions.  Secondly, the common agricultural policy and farmers ensured the food security of Europeans during the pandemic. It is necessary not only to continue this policy, but also to strengthen it, including financially, especially as additional obligations are to be imposed on farmers. Thirdly, the fund for the reconstruction of the EU economy must be of a subsidy rather than a loan nature, because already some countries, especially southern Europe, are no longer in debt. Fourthly and finally, the Commission should be commended for its swift decision-making on state aid in individual countries, but I would like to point out that this aid varies so much that it threatens the common market of the Union.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, seventy years ago Schuman promoted the Union after a cruel war which divided us. Today the enemy is a virus. Initially we reacted late and individually, but today the important thing is that we have learned. We are all united here, making physical and ideological boundaries disappear, approving a Resolution that satisfies what citizens expect of us: union and not division. This is the message we send to the Commission and the Council.  The pandemic leaves us with pain at the loss of thousands of loved ones. It leaves millions unemployed, the destruction of SMEs, all key to the development of Europe. That is why we must keep in mind that our resolution benefits and falls on each and every European. This compels us to be responsible for the use of resources. Their destiny is to get europeans ahead and leave no one behind. We must not allow particular political agendas to be implemented. The recovery plan should serve to lift Europe from the new reality, the Union of the 21st century.  The COVID-19 has become a transformation accelerator. Let us face the re-industrialization of Europe. Let's lead the digital transition. We defend agriculture, tourism, the green economy and the strength of our health systems and our health care, without ever giving up freedom, equality and solidarity. Let us ensure that citizens regain the pride of belonging to the Europe that protects them and guarantees them their development. If seventy years ago Schuman did it, today we must do it too.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this time the European Union has not been in a state of fluffy discussions for months and years. Now, however, we have to go a step further. With the European recovery plan financed by recovery bonds and new own resources, we can give a clear message to the whole world. Europe is there. Europe wants to remain free and cohesive, it wants to be united by its values of political freedom and a single social model. So if the plan came too late, without the advance as early as the next few months, if it could not move many hundreds of billions non-grant to the countries that need it, then we would not only lose solidarity but we would also have lost our common future, because no one, no one, can prosper if the common market collapses, if the value chains are broken. , if only a few countries have the strength to flood their economies with state aid and others remain stranded. It is therefore time to act, because only together can we find a way without betraying the fundamental principles on which our Union is founded.

name: Olivier CHASTEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament must be an actor in the process of socio-economic recovery and in the negotiations of the multi-year financial framework, which we want to be strong, in the context of a major economic crisis. The Union's multi-year budget must be ambitious, credible and united. To do so, it must understand our new own resources and have a strong common investment capacity. As for the stimulus package, it must be financed with fresh money, notably through recovery bonds guaranteed by the European Union budget. It must reflect the right balance between loans and subsidies. Ladies and gentlemen, this crisis requires us to chart a new economic trajectory towards a sustainable economy, guaranteeing European independence and securing our strategic interests. We need to focus on spending for the future, in relation to the climate challenge and strategic re-industrialization. More than ever, it is crucial for the Union to create the conditions for a sustainable, resilient and united Europe.

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as an Italian, I am very disappointed by the measures put in place by Europe to deal with the economic emergency following Covid-19: insufficient, late, but above all risky measures for our country which, let us not forget, is a net contributor to the Union and has never lacked resources and solidarity with the other Member States. Only the recovery plan is an exception, but on the modalities and conditions of implementation there is no certainty or rather, based on the European budget, we only know that these funds will not arrive before next year. Well, it is too late: to recover we need immediate resources and certainly not in the form of loans, because lending money to those who already know that they will not be able to return them is not an act of love, nor a gesture of solidarity, but only opportunism that conceals ulterior motives. I am referring, of course, to the ES MES: you have guaranteed us no conditionality, but to clarify this it was necessary to put it in black and white two weeks after the eurogroup agreement. The reality is that, after the emergency, Italy will have to pay back to the ESM installments of 4 billion euros per year, forcing us to cut welfare and impose new taxes. You tell us to trust, which is not the case, but the Italians no longer trust this European Union. Prove the opposite, because we would not like to be here in a few years' time with a President of the Commission who will come to plenary to apologise for applying reckless austerity, just as has already happened for our Greek friends.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, Europe is at a historic crossroads: either we solve the pandemic together or our institutions can very dangerously go down the path of irrelevance, and we have no right to throw away the European integration project that we have inherited from previous generations. It is not the time either to arouse low passions in our different countries, drawing a Europe of sin and another of virtue, especially when those who do fiscal avoidance practices do so every year. This Parliament is going to be clear. This time it is. We call for a Recovery Fund of at least two trillion euros, which are mostly with transfers, that no more burdens fall on the treasures of the Member States and with a system of own resources that allows repayment, both principal and interest. This is the instrument we need. And I am very concerned about the words of the President of the Commission today, who has explained absolutely nothing to us. I have a feeling they're coming back with a private resource mobilization plan, with magical multipliers that we know aren't going anywhere. Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, please live up to the historic moment, listen and read what we are going to vote for this week.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, what most people here are saying about the MFK and the recovery plan are frankly impossible to agree with. Certainly, the corona crisis demands solidarity. The cohesion funds will therefore have to be used differently and more specifically. But what is being proposed now goes far beyond that. A huge increase in the budget, new European taxes, public debt that the EU is going to take over from the Member States. This is one major move towards a transfer union, in which the distribution of income and burdens among the Member States is completely out of balance. In the meantime, the euro has lost the most important instrument for economic recovery, namely the devaluation of the national currency. In some situations it is probably even better to return to its own national currency, but then they have to have roadmaps in place. I therefore call on the Commission to look into this and to consider it. In any case, that seems to me to be a more meaningful way of thinking than the proposals that are now on the table.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Mr President, every crisis always acts as a tell-tale, and it will not have escaped the rule. The European Union emerges from this experience with the evidence of its fragilities. Today, we have to react. And for this, implement the means of genuine solidarity. But I think that means, in this debate on the budget and the stimulus package, to start by questioning the ends before considering the means. We wave a lot of big words and a lot of big numbers. But what is the use of money deployed by the European Union? Where is it really expected? How can we be useful? That is the question that I think we have to start by asking ourselves in the debate that awaits us. We also need to be able to react quickly and, from that point of view, I am surprised that we are spending so much time talking about the MFF when we are expected to have an urgent recovery plan. What business leader today claims to be able to build a seven-year strategy plan, when we are still in total confusion that this crisis is creating on the European economy? Finally, ladies and gentlemen, we will be expected tomorrow to build a European Union that is rethinking its relationship to globalisation. And that is the long-term challenge on which we must work: to build a Europe in which we can once again produce what we need, to build a Europe in which it will be possible for European countries to give masks to their nurses and medicines to their patients.  That, ladies and gentlemen, is what we are expected to be on. This is a major challenge for the future of Europe as a whole and I hope that we will rise to this challenge.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, what I have noticed very much in this unprecedented sanitary crisis, but also social and economic crisis, is the immense solidarity among our European population. Let us be clear that that same solidarity must resonate in the European Union's policies and the recovery plan that is on the way. Solidarity means looking at environmental and social justice. In European jargon, this means: based on the European Green Deal and on the pillar of social rights. That's very important. In addition, solidarity requires a large investment plan based on Eurobonds, as we ask here, best friend Maroš Šefčovič. But I would also like to emphasise this very strongly, on a fair and consolidated tax within the European Union, because that too is essential.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In recent weeks and months, we have had a rather lame discussion on European solidarity. I believe that in the long run we have to agree on how we deal with the issues of this matter, so that every time we suffer a small crisis or a major crisis, we do not somehow start from scratch, from scratch, from scratch, and try to build something that we have never seen before.  The template we actually have in the background is the template of the budget. It distributes the burden in a reasonably fair way. If you look at the German share, it is 30 times higher than the Bulgarian share, and I think that is a gesture of solidarity. The Finnish share is twice as high as the Bulgarian share, although we are also a relatively small country. So that if, in future, we are able to build the necessary brakes, the necessary resources, on the same principles as we have dealt with it on the issue of the budget, Then I think we can do this better than we have done this time.

name: Philippe OLIVIER
text: Mr President, I would like to mention a taboo subject in this great house that is Parliament: the decision of the German Constitutional Court on 5 May to require the ECB to justify its decisions under the European treaties. I do not want to get into a financial or even legal debate here. I would like to stick to the principles raised by this decision, what do I say, this ultimatum. With this specific tradition enshrining the power of judges in Germany, the magistrates of Karlsruhe acted as sovereignist whistleblowers. They came to reaffirm that the EU is not a federal state and that states remain masters of treaties and their national interests. As if nothing had happened, the Commission has mechanically reaffirmed the pre-eminence of European law over national law. "As if nothing had happened": this is how the behaviour of the EU, which is dealing with the accession of Kosovo or Macedonia when the health crisis turns to drama in Italy, could be summed up. You are like the driver on the wrong side on the highway, who continues at full speed ignoring the calls of headlights that come from opposite.

name: Alexandra GEESE
text: – Mr President, I strongly welcome the fact that the European institutions will make unprecedented efforts to turn this crisis into an opportunity and to make sure that harder-hit Member States will get the same chances to restart their economy. But I’m afraid we are not giving the same chances to the half of the population that is hit hardest – women – because they work in the sectors that suffer most. And when unemployment is skyrocketing, when we speak of a stimulus package for our economy, most consider investments in  hard infrastructure and digitalisation, and rightly so, but that’s exactly where the share of female labour is very, very low. On top of that, women have stepped up their endless hours of unpaid work to compensate for closed schools and childcare services and this is intolerable. For this, President von der Leyen, I’m counting on you. Women are looking at you. Women are organising. Make sure that the recovery fund offers a bright future and allows for investments that give a proper income to women as well as to men.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Someone here said we are in a historic moment. I would add that we are at the last moment to prove that Schuman's project is true and fair. This is the last moment to say here and now that we are together with the citizens, that there is a pandemic here and now, there is a crisis here and now, and we cannot say that in a year, in two or fifteen years' time. I wonder how many of you would dare with these statements to go to the suburbs of Paris to those who are starving, and to give their speeches, how many of you would dare to go to those who have garbage contracts and have lost income overnight, to drivers, transporters, small and medium-sized enterprises. We have one responsibility: we need to revalue the multiannual financial framework and budget in order to start by securing citizens. This is how our solidarity is to be manifested. All other concepts and plans must be subordinated to this. And let us not demand additional money from the Member States, let us find it in our own resources.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, Vice-President Šefčovič, the fact that Mrs von der Leyen has presented the new recovery fund here in this House fills us with hope. It's a front-to-front fund. An investment fund based on green deal priorities. A fund proportionate to the needs of the Member States. However, this new super-weapon, which is long overdue, must not be burdened with additional debt by countries such as my country Greece which have already been hit by the debt crisis and have lost 25% of their GDP in the past decade. To enable economies to be supported mainly by grants, 'mostly grants', just as we say in our text, which we will vote on tomorrow by a large majority here in the European Parliament. To be combined with all the other available financial instruments, the quantitative easing of the European Central Bank, the investment programme of the European Investment Bank and the very low interest rate loans of the Support Mechanism as well as with indirect needs of national health systems that absolutely need to be financed. What is certain is that the challenge we are facing at the moment is an existential challenge for the European Union. And I'd like to conclude by saying this: we're all you know on the same boat. If the single market does not work, if our businesses are not strengthened with liquidity, if we do not maintain the cohesion of our societies and do not cope with the wave of unemployment that is coming, none of us will be rescued, nor will it travel, nor will it buy, nor will technological equipment have, no cars, no tulips.

name: Pierre LARROUTUROU
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, in just three days, almost one million citizens have already signed Avaaz's letter which says that they are counting on you to succeed in this 'climate and employment' budget. As rapporteur of the budget, I think that one of the solutions to have a very ambitious budget is to create a tax on financial transactions. When I bought this phone, I paid a 19% VAT. Nineteen. For basic food products, VAT is only 5.5%. But even the poorest families have to pay 5.5% to contribute to the collective effort. On the other hand, those who buy shares on the financial markets pay 0.0%. Zero point zero. Because they are poorer than the poorest? No, of course not. There is an urgent need to create a financial transaction tax. Already in 2011, the Barroso Commission had proposed this project, which can now create 57 billion euros. The text is written, there is only to move forward politically. Despite Brexit, despite the crisis, a financial transaction tax can bring in 57 billion euros. So what are we waiting for? That would be ten times more than the digital tax. Mrs von der Leyen, it is time to put finance at the service of life. It is time for financial markets to contribute to a climate and employment pact. (Applause)

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: – Mr President, the global pandemic is rapidly turning into an economic crisis, to which we must respond vigorously, time is running out. We are in Europe right now negotiating a new budget, and that should be our main answer. We need to rely on programmes that we know work, such as robust cohesion policies. And we should also focus on investment, and in this I welcome the Commission's proposal to strengthen investment instruments even further. But let us also focus on assistance that will be directed directly to citizens and businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises or tourism entrepreneurs who are worried about their future. Let us support employment, think about regions, let us also focus on innovation and digital technologies. Let us take advantage of and strengthen the possibilities of a common internal market. An agreement on the European Union budget and further support for the recovery of the economy must come as soon as possible. So let's not miss this chance!

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the bureaucrats in Brussels are masters of financial illusionism, a real art of peddding small sums as if they were billions of euros. They're harsh words, maybe you won't like them, but they're not my sack flour. Instead, they represent the Financial Times' view of the recovery fund, which at the moment is an empty box despite the hopes of citizens and businesses, who called for swift and incisive action. I am expressing my disappointment at the fact that the first tentative signs of overcoming the health crisis preceded the billions announced with great pomp by the European institutions. Time has been wasted, too much has been lost, even someone has tried grotesquely to blame those who do not even take part in the meetings of the Eurogroup and the European Council, when it would have been appropriate, for once, to take a bath of humility, recognizing that many of the Union's unsustainable dogmatic principles, from state aid legislation to the Stability and Growth Pact, are not enough. , have been denied because they are unenforceable in a state of crisis. On a positive note, however, is found in the conclusions of President Charles Michel, who calls for the importance of increasing the Union's strategic autonomy and producing essential goods in Europe: in practice, a step backwards from the overdose of neoliberalism that we have been denouncing for years, unheeded.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are all in a collective crisis experience here in Europe, and that gives us a foretaste of what lies ahead if we continue to steer fully into the climate crisis.  And to all those in this House and in the national governments who are trying to use this situation to undermine the climate policy of the Union and the nation states, I say to them: they will have to answer for the next generation.  And one thing is becoming apparent in this crisis: the link between well-funded public health systems and the amount of people dying from the virus. Anyone who is still calling for privatisations in the health and care sector and does not understand that we need properly funded public health care throughout Europe has not learned the lesson of COVID-19.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: – Mr President, many Europeans are probably not familiar with the traditional Chinese ritual of prostrating yourself: kowtow. Today, this means showing too much respect to someone in authority. The Commission erased criticism of China from its Corona disinformation report. The EU representation in Beijing accepted Chinese censorship of an op-ed by EU ambassadors. The EU Council discussed the Wuhan virus during its last meeting, but carefully avoided any reference to China, the Communist Party and the need for an international inquiry. This despite our knowledge that the Chinese Communist Party covered up the outbreak while vacuuming the world of personal protective equipment. They sealed Wuhan from the rest of China while allowing super-spreaders to board flights to Milan and New York.  Stop this kowtowing!

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, the European Union is a solidarity union in good times and bad. My appeal is for heads of state to show solidarity and unity now. The outcome of the crisis is to invest massively and support the most affected industries tourism, services, transport, but not at the expense of other policies, such as regional development policy, which needs predictability and sustainability.  We need to invest through an ambitious Multiannual Financial Framework with more own resources and a recovery fund with a serious part as a grant, but not a Multiannual Financial Framework at the expense of the Fund or vice versa. Let us not solve the urgent problems of the present by undermining the future and risking deepening regional differences in the European Union.  Commissioner Bossovic, through you, I would like to address again the President, Mrs Ursula von der Leyen, with an appeal to address European citizens directly through the public televisions of each Member State to share with them both their human empathy and the measures that the European Union is taking. No one should be left alone, but we must also not let misinformation and conspiracy theories lead and disconnect citizens.

name: Nils UŠAKOVS
text: – Mr President, it is absolutely true: spending billions of European taxpayers’ money, we should use the momentum and support modern economy, digital economy, Green Deal first. And probably sometimes we should stick to the principle: do not resuscitate. But my point is – I come from the Baltics, from Latvia – our country went through enormous, dramatic, economic transition back in the nineties, going from planned to market. And we’ve seen new sectors emerging from scratch. We have seen traditional old sectors collapsing, basically, instantly. And the price for this inevitable transition was tens of thousands of Latvians losing their jobs and not being able to get back to the labour market anymore. They were talented, they were educated, but their skills were not demanded anymore. Each Eastern European nation in the European Union has experience like this. The new ambitious MFF, paralleled by the even more ambitious recovery fund, must, on the one hand, help us in modernising the economy; on the other hand, help us in modernising skills for those workers who come from sectors which are not that modern.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Council has finally decided on a serious programme of action to deal with the coronavirus crisis. Of course, he could and should have done it sooner. We now expect the Commission to present an operational proposal for the recovery plan appropriate for quality and quantity: what is at stake is not only to defeat Covid-19 but to make Europe resilient to the disintegration virus which, yes, is strongly fuelled by foreign countries. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are not only being asked for economic intervention to support countries and populations in difficulty, we are being asked to restore a dream, a vision and a soul to this Europe. Everyone is called upon to make complex and even controversial choices. Let us not just ask ourselves what we have to do, but why we have to do it! In answering this question we will find the courage, ambition and vision of the future that we need to face the difficult time we are given to live.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to focus on the discussion in the European Council of 23 April on illegal Turkish natural gas drilling in Cypriot waters. We are currently seeing a lot of rhetoric about European solidarity. But now is certainly the time to actually demonstrate our determination by showing real solidarity with an EU Member State.  The Turkish Government has made it clear that it is not interested in complying with accepted international law. In addition to the attempted illegal drilling activities, there are also attempts to smuggle weapons into Libya in defiance of the United Nations arms embargo, destabilizing the entire eastern Mediterranean. You will no doubt have seen the joint declaration by Cyprus, Greece, France, Egypt and the United Arab Emirates condemning Turkish activities. This is a good and important step, but we certainly need stronger expressions of support for Syria.  Let us be clear: Turkey is attacking the European Union, and this is something that we can no longer tolerate.

name: Andżelika Anna MOŻDŻANOWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, all Member States, our citizens, our families and businesses expect the European Union to play an active role in the fight against the social and economic crisis. We have a multiannual financial framework ahead of us for very difficult times. Today it is above all the flexibility of the use of European funds and the guarantee of new funds for the Union. The Multiannual Financial Framework is the foundation for boosting the European economy and fighting the crisis, and let us recall that the European Commission's economic forecast for today is a huge fall in the UNION's GDP of more than 7%.  Businesses are struggling with the crisis, many companies are in danger of collapse and the European economy is at a standpoint. Companies are the flywheel of our development and the social security of our citizens. Let us not forget this. Let us not plaive the cohesion policy resources that are the basis and important element of supporting our investments. Let us not cling to the agricultural policy that ensures food self-sufficiency for European citizens.  Today, the European economy definitely needs a supply of new money. We must take the fight against tax fraud seriously, strengthen the tax cooperation of the Member States of the Union in order to eliminate tax fraud and havens. New taxes can be a source of revenue: a digital tax on financial transactions, carbon footprint or production from third countries.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am following with great concern the debate we are currently having on the MFF and the building fund.  Everyone was fine when we pushed the building fund onto the MFF. It was only afterwards that the Member States, who wanted to do so, realised that they did not really want to pay any more. This game was actually very predictable. It is clear that this policy will affect those budget chapters that are important so far in the MFF.  Let me give you the example of agriculture: in THE COVID era, when farmers have certainly fed us, we have left only EUR 80 million for 27 Member States for agriculture as a crisis measure – the United States, for example.B. has EUR 19 billion left – and that is for a policy that is our policy, which we are responsible for and for which we must stand up. We must act as a Parliament on this. Agriculture still needs the money it has had so far. We in this Parliament should also not agree to the new MFF, also next year, and a proposal that says otherwise.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe has faced the most difficult challenge since the end of World War II and, therefore, we must act more than ever united, having the same ambition and political courage demonstrated by the founding fathers of the Union.  We must abandon the old political, economic and legal dogmas, and have the courage to rebuild from solidarity a new, more integrated and resilient Europe. To this end, this house must play a central role in politically oriented and budgetary decision-making in the creation of the recovery and transformation plan and in the negotiation of an ambitious MFF.  We have to put the two trillion euros fresh on the table, without false debates or financial deceptions. Money needs to circulate and reach the citizens, businesses, regions and countries that need it most as soon as possible. Because, as Adenauer said, we all live under the same sky, but none of us have the same horizon.  Let us work together to reach the same horizon and share a common destiny that leaves no one behind. Let us demonstrate the strength of this Parliament by voting, all of us, on the Joint Resolution.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, a few days ago, in the midst of this pandemic, we celebrated Europe. 70 years of a project of peace and union among Europeans, fulfilling the plan that "Europe would not be done at once, not according to a single plan". Faced with the difficulty, we are all in the same boat and, for my part, I will not be on the side of those who want Europe to sink.  The strategy for the economic recovery of this pandemic must be focused on people, Europeans, young people who are already facing the second major crisis of their lives, entrepreneurs struggling every day to pay wages, the unemployed who are experiencing great difficulties. It is for all of these that we need a plan and a recovery fund that transforms and modernises our economies. And let everyone know that it is not Parliament, but the Council, who is blocking such urgent responses. Here, let us do what we have: to ensure that Europe has more of a future than a past.

name: Giuseppe FERRANDINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, mr von der Leyen, we ask you to launch an ambitious plan that meets the needs of citizens and businesses affected by Covid-19, because we are on the threshold of an unprecedented economic disaster. The resolution we are tabling today is a demonstration of responsibility and unity at such a difficult time, but also a demand for parliament's centrality: we cannot continue to hold the Union hostage to governments, we must invest a great deal and do so quickly, and this time the focus must be on citizens and businesses, not as in 2008 when the banks were preferred to the former. EUR 2 000 billion is barely enough to support the economies of the Member States. We expect the recovery plan not to be an empty box but to be made up of bonds and loans that are also non-re-purchase and be tied to green transition and economic resilience. Citizens need immediate answers. The tourism sector, the transport sector, the manufacturing sector and all small and medium-sized enterprises can no longer wait: the timer for a financial catastrophe is about to expire and, in any case, economic measures must not be taken away from the Structural Funds. Here today we decide ... (some missing words) or not!

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr While we are fighting covid-19, Europe is in the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. Europe now needs a strong rescue package and a modern budget that builds Europe's competitiveness. At the same time, however, we need to have a responsible economic policy, and therefore the rescue package should not consist of a majority of subsidies and direct payments. Rather, it should be about loans; and loans to be repaid.  Future economic policy should be more about new reforms, and less about new taxes. Mr President, we stand up for European cooperation and solidarity, but the Swedish Moderates and Christian Democrats cannot support this resolution.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, almost one in ten Europeans will be unemployed this year because of the corona crisis, the European Commission predicts. Behind these statistics are people who see their dreams and desires disappear and who are uncertain about the future. I think now is the time to invest in people, to keep them working or get them back to work. Achieving the social pillar is not free. Creating sustainable jobs is not free. Poverty alleviation is not free and with some hand clapping from the balconies and just expressing our appreciation we do not get there. In the MFK, we need to focus more on social funds such as the European Globalisation Fund and the Youth Employment Initiative. If we choose to invest in people now, we will avoid a worse crisis and we will reap the benefits.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Mr President, I thank President von der Leyen and President Michel for reaffirming, in particular, the importance of the European Green Pact in the recovery plan. However, the recovery plan must also aim at convergence towards a strategy of European sovereignty in areas as strategic as health, as has been mentioned by many people, but also in other areas. In food, to support producers and farmers, who have this strategy of autonomy and independence, extremely important to me. In energy too: we need a recovery plan that takes this into account in order to be as independent as possible in energy matters. It is about European sovereignty and the confidence of the Europeans. Certainly also in digital, which must be revived thanks to this plan to stimulate the economy and bring this independence to the level of Europe. And finally, in defense and security. For all this, we must also have the means of our own at European level. I would of course argue that Europe should finally be able to have its own tax revenues, in particular through a tax on kerosene and a tax on GAFA, so that there is this coordination at European level and that the Commission has its own resources for the recovery plan, for the future and for European sovereignty.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Mr President, colleagues, we welcome the important step taken in the last Council which allows the Union to issue debt together, without this having to be accompanied by a punishment for the member countries. But the crisis we face is unprecedented in the period after World War II. That's why we need all our firepower right now! The recovery plan that the Commission is drawing up must be very ambitious. It is not enough to raise some money in the market, many multipliers and a lot of marketing to recover the European economy. We need investment, transfers to families, to stimulate the demand and confidence of entrepreneurs, because we want and can save a lot of jobs in Europe.  We therefore also need another role of the European Central Bank. These are not normal times. Monetary policy also has to change and a lot! Europeans are being heroes in fighting the virus. The European institutions must now show solidarity with those most affected.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Europe's foundations are the people, and they need our help now and not at some point. The answer to this crisis is therefore obvious: we need more courage, more solidarity and, above all, much more Europe.  Let us be courageous and get the money for the necessary post-crisis reconstruction from those who have so far paid very little tax or none at all: from the large international corporations. Let us be European and, above all, we support those Member States that have suffered and are suffering particularly badly from this crisis. And that includes Corona bonds. Finally, let us show solidarity with women. This is not a minority programme now, it is about half the population. Domestic violence has increased dramatically, and the economic impact on women is particularly drastically felt and visible. Single parents in particular suffer greatly from snorting the household, perhaps having to teach children on the side and, of course, having to work – be it in front of the screen, be it in the supermarkets or where else they are employed. We therefore need a women's fund, and we should also strive for this.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: – Mr President, President von der Leyen has expressed her goal to strengthen and unite Europe, and yet I hear from rumours that military mobility, the flagship programme to strengthen and unite Europe, has suffered severe cuts or even been thrown out of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). That is not good. We must not compromise on our security. Military mobility is the most practical cooperation programme between NATO and the EU. We should not waste it. Secondly, on the Green Deal. The Green Deal, as important as it is, is a very expensive programme. We need to make sure that the MFF allocates sufficient resources in order to enable farmers and businesses to achieve these very difficult goals. If we don’t do so, then we will contribute to their downfall by adding more restrictions on them at a time when farmers are suffering the most.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – Mr President, there is a group of people in Europe who embody the idea of the single market every single day: frontier workers. The pandemic has shown that they do not have sufficient legal protection, that for them the single market does not work well in difficult times. So when we talk about recovery, the question is: to what? My answer: to a truly functioning single market where people and goods really move in a free way. I saw the result of closed borders in Silesia on the Polish, German and Czech borders. So many people there lost their jobs simply because Member States acted selfishly. We need to handle the situation. The European recovery plan needs to regulate the rights of frontier workers. The EU economic integration model needs to be much deeper. We must make the European project a federal project. It is time now or never. Europa braucht keine Grenzen. Evropa nepotřebuje žádné hranice. Europa nie potrzebuje żadnych granic.

name: David CASA
text: 'Sur President, settur ieħor ta' ħaddiema li ntlaqat ħażin ħafna b'din il-pandemija huwa dak tal-midja. Il-ġurnalisti wkoll komplew jirriskjaw ħajjithom f'xogħolhom. Iżda, naturalment, kif nafu, ir-reklami, u b'hekk, l-introjtu tal-kumpaniji, naqas. Għalhekk, jiena, flimkien ma'kollegi oħra minn din il-Kamra, qed ninsistu mal-Gumssjoni biex ma nħallux lis-settur tal-media houses waħedhom, u naraw x'għajnuna finanzjarja dawn gandħhom bżonn, fosthom, pereżemp hemm min issuġerixxa fond permanenti għall-ġurnalimuż. Irridu niftakru li l-midja għandha rwol kru大jali f'demokrazija. U ebda Stat Membru ma jaffordja li jkollu flower-midja f'pajjiżu dgħajfa. Wisq nibża' li l-kriżi finanzjarja li ġabet magħha din il-pandemija qiegħda tħalli effett ħażin ħafna fuq il-midja, u allura anke fuq id-demokraziji ta' pajjiżi differenti. Jien se nkompli naħdem flimkien mal-kollegi tiegħi ta' din il-Kamra biex din l-għajnuna tingħata malajr kemm jista' jkun ħalli jkollna demokrazija aktar b'saħħitha.

name: Elena YONCHEVA
text: – Mr President, life and health have no price. We should spare no resources for the recovery. But the most vulnerable cannot recover as fast as the strongest. Europe on different speeds, Europe at 27 speeds, is not acceptable. Let me highlight three questions. First, the recovery plan should not be agreed by government behind closed doors. The plan must be subject to strong democratic oversight by the Parliament. Second, it’s very important that the resources, the funds, reach those in need and not some oligarchs. The Commission needs to monitor for real how Member States are using those funds. My last point is on the rule of law. If we allow any further deterioration on the rule of law, we risk reaching the point of no return. I urge the Commission to provide dedicated financial support to free and independent media.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Mr President! Covid-19 hurts - to those who lose loved ones, their life's work or their work. If it hurts others, it's a natural charity act to reach out to help. It can be done in many ways, but never, so that addiction develops without the need for one's own responsibility and space to adapt as it is best for the individual - man as well as the nation. That is why it is a dangerous decision that is coming through the European Parliament. Not because of the intention, it is good enough, but because the content is more Union, tax screws in Brussels and a distribution of almost infinite billions without conditions - totally unhealthy for what has made the European Union what we know today and want to preserve through the corona crisis. The EU is a global role model for democracy, green transition and innovation. We are because, until now, we have hailed the sovereign responsibility and cooperation of nation states, in terms of moderation of the common economy, the focus on cross-border challenges and the value of learning and lifting each other in healthy and fair competition to be the best. That is why I am not voting in favour of the resolution.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, the economic recovery plan that the European Commission is going to present must be able to pass two fundamental tests: the credibility test and the solidarity test. The test of credibility, because it cannot be based so on financial illusionism. You have to have enough resources to be able to deal with this unprecedented crisis. Then the solidarity test, because it needs to mobilise investment where it is needed without precipitating Member States into a new sovereign debt crisis. And this only with debt securities issued by the Commission, guaranteed by the European budget and transferred to the States more by grants than by loans. A credible and supportive plan. That's what it takes. The European Parliament is not asking for more than what is needed. He doesn't ask for more, but he doesn't need any less either.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Mr President, I would like to just make one additional remark after having listened to this debate for nearly two hours with great interest. This pandemic knows no borders; neither should the EU’s response. That is why the chairs of the committees in this Parliament who deal with external policies have issued a joint statement. We have called for close cooperation with our neighbours and partners, both in the fight against the pandemic as an imminent health issue and against its serious future consequences.  In the past few weeks, we have seen remarkable efforts of cooperation and acts of goodwill, but we have also had to witness increased isolationism, harsh competition between nations for medicines and equipment, intense propaganda and disinformation by third countries, and a sharp rise in cyber—attacks. This shows this pandemic has a global meaning. It’s a global challenge.  The Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) will be the main instrument to tackle this challenge we face within the European Union, but also to support our partners not only, but foremost, in our immediate neighbourhood. This has to be covered in the future MFF.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first I would like to thank everyone for this debate. There was a lot of passion. There was a lot of ambition in your statements. What I think I saw most across all the interventions today is that there is a clear push for making sure that the EU, our Union, our Europe, will emerge from this crisis stronger, more modern, more sustainable and more resilient. I think these have been the calls presented by the leaders – Ms García Pérez, Mr Cioloş and Mr Lamberts. I cannot tell you how much we in the Commission appreciate the close cooperation with this House, especially over the last few weeks, where your quick decision—making helped us to be able to deliver to our citizens what was needed the most. We all had to focus on how to save as many lives as possible at the beginning, then on how to preserve as many jobs as possible, and now we are discussing together how we are going to relaunch the European economy and how we are going to recover from this dramatic crisis.  I would really like to thank you for that because, with that cooperation, we have already been able to deliver, over the last few weeks, more than 200 measures, some of the very important legislative proposals adopted by you, which really went in the direction of how to help people on the ground concretely to overcome this unprecedented crisis. Thanks to the heroic efforts of our health professionals and thanks to the discipline of our citizens, we are finally seeing that the terrible numbers of corona crisis victims are slowly going down. We all know that this was a very difficult period, but the biggest test is still ahead of us: how to recover from this crisis, how to relaunch and restart our economy, and how to get back to normal. This could indeed be, as Mr Weber described, the Schuman moment of our generation. Therefore, I very much appreciate this debate because, as Mr Silva Pereira said, we need to be ambitious and bold to meet this challenge, this test, of European solidarity and credibility. How do we want to achieve that? Just let me quickly recap some of the major features of the proposals we are currently working on. We want to base our response on a powerful future long—term budget, a multiannual framework with a strong recovery instrument which would dramatically boost the financial firepower of the EU. I would definitely call this an unprecedented ambition. So here I would beg to differ with Mr Verhofstadt that this is ‘business as usual’. I was personally involved in the negotiations on the last three financial perspectives and what we are proposing right now has never been done before. It’s very bold and very ambitious. I believe that, with your support, we can deliver on this challenge which is ahead of all of us. I would like to reassure you that we want to reinforce all the policies which work and which are, I would say, battle—tested. We would like to make sure that we will top up the cohesion funds and focus the top—up especially on those who have suffered the most during the crisis. We want to use and improve the work of InvestEU and of Horizon, which is so important for supporting our scientists. And we would never forget the very important social aspect of our work for the European Union. We need to tackle poverty, we need to make sure that the Just Transition Fund works efficiently, and of course we cannot forget about women, parents and all the issues related to gender balance, which will be so important for our recovery. On top of that, we are bringing to the table a new solvency instrument to prevent bankruptcies caused by this crisis, and we also want to develop a new health programme that would prepare us better for the future. So, once again, I repeat, this is definitely not ‘business as usual’. This is a very ambitious response to the current crisis. I would like also to respond to the calls of Mr Lamberts, Mr Eickhout and Mr Ertug by saying we definitely want to use this new financial firepower to bounce our economy forward. We want to make it greener and more sustainable. I think that this crisis has taught us the lesson that we have to be more resilient through strategic autonomy and technological sovereignty. These are the areas where we need to be much more active than before, and this is our goal. To all those colleagues who have been highlighting the importance of own resources, I would like to reassure you that we are very actively working with all options. Most of these have already been mentioned here in this debate. We are going to present proposals which we believe will be acceptable to all and which could be approved by your votes and by the Member States. It’s very clear that, if we have to deliver on this challenge, we can deliver only with your full involvement and with clear oversight and scrutiny from the European Parliament.  If you allow me, Mr President, before concluding, I will make just two quick remarks on issues which are not related to the main theme, but have been raised in this House. As they are so important, I just want briefly to react to them, these being the questions from Mr Olivier and Mr Omarjee concerning the German Constitutional Court’s recent ruling. Here I would like to say that, despite the fact that we are studying the ruling of the German Constitutional Court in great detail, I think our President has made it very clear. She clearly said that, when it comes to the primacy in Europe of EU law and the independence of the European Central Bank, these are basic principles which we are ready to safeguard and defend if necessary, even using the option of infringement proceedings. So we are clearly working on it.  To Ms Yoncheva, I would like to reassure her that we are working on the report on the rule of law, where we will study all the known issues, but also on how our governments have been using special powers during this difficult period and how to make sure that we will, as quickly as possible, bounce back to normally—functioning democratic systems. All this will be brought to your attention and to your table at the latest in September. Once again, Mr President, thank you very much to everyone for this debate, for the ideas, for the encouragement and for the ambition I have felt in this House.

name: David McALLISTER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, I’m happy to address you again in person. Let me also thank you for this very useful debate. We will convey your views to my colleagues and to the President of the European Council and his team. We face extraordinary circumstances, but the situation only strengthens our resolve to work harder for the benefit of our citizens and our economies. As President Michel told you, our shared objective is to build at EU level a long-term response to the dramatic consequences of the COVID-19 crisis. This will complement the rapid and wide EU support already deployed with your help these last weeks. Today, the President of the Commission gave us an outline of the modified MFF and an ambitious recovery instrument. We are yet to receive details of the Commission’s proposal, and you will understand, therefore, that I am not in a position to comment on the substance today. The proposals will have to be analysed in the appropriate fora, and guidance from the European Council will be needed for the Council to form its position on the text. Our next MFF should be the cornerstone of the recovery of the European economy, of the rebuilding and the re-establishment of the functioning of the single market in the post-COVID period to ensure the massive public and private investments needed. It should have greater investment potential, especially in the initial years of the new financial perspective. The post-crisis European Union economy should become resilient and more self-sufficient, and for the recovery to be swift and successful, cohesion, convergence as well as solidarity will be of utmost importance. Continuous cooperation between our institutions will be an essential part of all of this process. The Presidency is firmly committed to maintaining the existing good working relations that we have established in our response to the crisis. We will therefore continue to be attentive to Parliament’s views on these very important files.  In this spirit, I have taken good note of the legislative initiative report and of the resolution you are preparing. These are useful reminders of where the European Parliament stands in the context of crisis. Good interinstitutional cooperation will also be essential for our sectorial work. We will need to work together to ensure a timely adoption of sectorial programmes and we will look forward to working with you on them. I look forward to the continued cooperation between our two institutions to prepare the ground for an ambitious, forward-looking MFF and to provide a strong response to our current and future challenges.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote on the resolution on 'New MFF, own resources and plan for the reconstruction of the economy' will take place on Thursday 14 May 2020 and Friday 15 May 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: in writing. – One of the fundamental principles on which the Union is built is the principle of solidarity and I believe that this should be clearly demonstrated in the EU's response to the COVID-19 pandemic, immediate measures to tackle the crisis and the development of a long-term plan to rebuild and support the most affected countries and regions. The health crisis has put many citizens in an extremely difficult social and financial situation, putting pressure on businesses and serious difficulties for the health, social and economic systems of countries.  I urge the Commission to propose an ambitious but at the same time realistic MFF and recovery plan that also meets the Union's commitments to move towards a sustainable, circular economy. I believe that this can be done by including the budget for the new recovery fund in the MFF. The MFF budget must be increased and new own resources added to it in order to avoid adding an additional financial burden to the budget of the Member States.  The development of measures and their financing must be based on the objective of preventing the deepening of social inequalities and unemployment caused by the crisis, returning to stable economic growth, strengthening the social and economic cohesion of regions and countries and fully restoring the Union's competitiveness.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: Writing. – Under the MFF, financial resources will also be made available for the 'Green Deal' – a paltry EUR 1 trillion. The European Green Deal is a concept presented by the European Commission with the aim of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions to zero in the European Union by 2050, making it the first continent to become climate neutral. Economies are on the decline due to the shutdown. Where should EUR 1 trillion come from to finance a completely fact-free and insane climate delusion ideology? Nevertheless, the Commission stubbornly intends to stick to its 'green deal'. The "Corona crisis" has brought to light the madness: although there have been hardly any cars on the road in recent weeks and emissions have been significantly reduced, nitrogen oxide levels have not fallen.
