In the light of this realization, the demand for a diesel driving ban – which, incidentally, represents the expropriation of car owners – and a change to a sinfully expensive and ecologically questionable electrification of road traffic are exposed for what they are: complete nonsense! Instead of "investing " 1 trillion euros in green nonsense," it is better to think about how to support families who have significant economic problems as a result of the impact of the Corona crisis. What we need is not a "green deal" – no, we need a "family deal."

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – It seems to me that the negotiations on the european Union's new seven-year budget are too focused on the volume of the budget. We are talking too much about massive packages and own resources. The 1% of gross national income concentrated in the European Union budget cannot mechanically offset the 7.4% recession forecast for this year. Therefore, rather than the volume of the budget, we should focus on how to make the most of scarce budgetary resources. We should pay more attention to the European Green Treaty, the Digital Agenda and how to ensure Europe's sovereignty in strategic sectors.  In the crisis, we widely use teleworking and distance learning and the possibilities of e-government. These options vary greatly from one Member State to another. Remote voting is a hot topic in all Member States. A truly reliable remote voting system is based on a strong digital identity. Unfortunately, Europeans also use Google, Facebook or Apple solutions to identify single sign services. Where are the European solutions? The voting system used by the European Parliament is also based on the logic of the fax machine. It's so last day! We must ensure a strong digital identity for the citizens of all the Member States of the European Union, guaranteed by the government. The next multiannual budget must be much more focused on digital developments.

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: Writing. – The low absorption of European Structural and Investment Fund (ESI Fund) resources over time has been a weak point in terms of achieving EU policy objectives. Many studies underline that maximising the impact of funding on the economy requires significant improvements in terms of simplification of procedures and sound financial management in order to increase the accessibility of stakeholders to European funds and to ensure their proper use. The proposal for a regulation on common provisions of the European Commission's Funds for the next MFF 2021-2027 takes a step in this direction. However, the great socio-economic impact of the pandemic requires more drastic measures. The MFF 2021-2027 must ensure that there is enough money but also that it reaches those who need it most quickly. The disbursement of money must go hand in hand with the changing reality to enable small businesses, universities and our local self-government to implement their projects effectively. In conclusion, 'new normality' in the pandemic era requires increased flexibility, adaptability and a reduction in red tape in the management of Community funds in the new programming period in order for Europe to meet the expectations of its citizens.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: in writing. – I would like to welcome the joint resolution, which calls for a strong recovery package with an adjusted MFF at its core. This massive recovery package should provide an investment impulse to transform our economies and strengthen their resilience through the pooling of strategic investments to support SMEs. It should also increase job opportunities to mitigate the impact of the crisis on workers and consumers. Furthermore, SMEs, which are the backbone of our economy, need reduced bureaucracy and more fit—for—purpose regulations. The issue of new and increasing state aid disparities between Member States should be addressed, as this creates damage to our Single Market. I welcome the statement of the European Commission President that the European Parliament will be involved in the scrutiny process of the overall Recovery Plan. Even if urgent, it should indeed still follow the democratic process. Let us not forget about people. European citizens must be at the heart of the longer-term vision of our recovery strategy, as crises go together with increasing poverty and socio—economic instability. For all these reasons, I urge that the Recovery Package become operational this year to address social and economic inequalities as soon as possible.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The COVID 19 crisis has the greatest impact on vulnerable groups, leading to increasing inequalities, poverty, unemployment and social inequalities, as well as the threat of social and employment standards in Europe. For this, we need to develop the right response and measures. This crisis has shown the need to revise the multiannual financial perspective and adapt it to the challenges that have arisen. We need an ambitious MFF in line with the expectations of EU citizens, which provides the eu's political commitments and ambitions with the necessary funding, which has a strong social dimension and is aligned with the objectives of the European Pillar of Social Rights, the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDGs) and the objective of gender equality, in order to ensure that economic recovery strengthens territorial cohesion and competitiveness and takes into account social and economic inequalities and the most affected by the crisis , e.g. the needs of women, minorities and those on or below the poverty line. The MFF must mobilise funds for sustainable social policies aimed at reducing poverty and social exclusion , in particular as regards the European Guarantee of the Child for Child Poverty and Its Reduction and other measures.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – The European Union is entering the stage of preparing for the elimination of the economic and social consequences caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.  The basis of the European recovery will be the new EU Multiannual Financial Framework and the plan to relaus the European economy, and in adopting them it is essential to ensure that the European Commission, and in particular the Council, does not seek to bypass Parliament. Covid-19 is an additional reason for the level and priorities of the MFF to be reconsidered and to be brought into line with the recovery plan, without jeopardising the implementation of existing programmes and priorities. Reconstruction will require additional, fresh money that can be provided, e.g. through European reconstruction bonds, innovative own resources (e.g. EU emissions trading system income, non-recycled plastics duties, carbon taxes for imports of certain products from third countries) and the abolition of corrective mechanisms for Germany, Austria, the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark.  The compromise text of the resolution gives the impression that (once again) finances are at the forefront, while in this crisis it is essential that our focus is maintained on people, especially the most vulnerable groups, such as the elderly, people with disabilities, the homeless, migrants and refugees, social affairs, the environment and the insistence on the rule of law.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: in writing. – In view of the delays in the adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021 - 2027, it is essential to carry out a contingency plan in case no agreement is reached for the entry into force of the new MFF on 1 January 2021. The new contingency plan is a response by the European Parliament to provide security to European citizens, but it is also a mechanism for responding immediately to the social and economic consequences of the Covid-19 outbreak. This contingency plan is an essential instrument that also contributes to the economic recovery of Member States and their regions. In the interim period up to the presentation of the MFF, I reiterate the importance of the 21-27 package to take into account regional development policies, while safeguarding the principles advocated by Cohesion Policy and taking into account in a similar light the exception regime provided for safeguarding the interests of the Outermost Regions, which play a key role for the European Union.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. – Europe is currently experiencing an unprecedented crisis due to the outbreak of COVID-19. European citizens and their prosperity must be at the heart of the recovery strategy. We stress our position on a strong recovery package, focused on the needs of citizens and on further budget development. A strong plan is needed to support the economies of EU countries, society and citizens tested by the pandemic, amounting to EUR 2 trillion. It is very important to stress that the recovery plan must accompany the next Multiannual Financial Framework, without adversely affecting existing and upcoming European programmes.

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: bil-miktub. – Dan il-Parliament għandu bilfors jitlob lill-Kummissjoni Ewropea f'qasir żmien tipproponi pjan ta' kontinġenza dwar il-qafas finanzjarju 2021-2027, għax minkejj t-taħdit jista' jissokta, hemm programmi ta' finanzjament ta' edukazzjoni u rièerka, ta' sostenn lill-intrapriżi ż-żgħar u l-fondi ta' koeżjoni fost oħrajn, li l-ebda reġjun, kbir jew żgħir, ma jiflaħ jeħlu mqar għal ftit. Nemmen li lkoll nifhmu l-ħtieġa, li filwaqt li dak dak neèessarju qabel, jibqa' neèssarju issa, il-qafas finanzjarju Ewropew irid bl-aktar mod effiaèi jtaffi l-impatt economics fuq il-ħaddiema in l-family, in jnaqqas il-konsegwenzi soèjali ta' pandemic bla preèedent, billi jagħti aktar flessibilità in billi jsaħħaħ is-sostenn finanzjarja. Lil hinn mill-baġit regolars, l-Ewropa teħtieġ Pjan ta' Rkupru economics qawwi li jagħti prijorità lill-oqsma li ntlaqtu l-agħar mill-effetti tal-pandemic, bħat-turiżmu in s-settura diversi dipendenti fuqu; L-ivjaġġar bl-ajru in L-baħar. Pjan ta' Rkupru serju għandu juża għotjiet biex dawk is-setturi l-aktar milquta jiffaèèjaw in-nuqqas ta' likwidità. Illum you nifhmu you s-suèèess economics jitkejjel bil-livell tal-għajxien tal-family, nafu tajjeb l-sameolu economics jrid ikompli jipprovdi riżorsi biżejed biex nipproteġu x-xogħol in nmant s-servizzi pubblièi inkluż fis-saħħa, fl-edukazzjoni in fis-sigurtà tal-komunitajiet tagħna.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – The framework of demands associated with responding to the consequences of COVID-19 involves health protection, in particular the most vulnerable groups, the defence of the income of workers and their families, the defence of employment with rights and the relaunch of economic activity, which, in the case of countries such as Portugal, with high dependence and external subordination, should assume a special focus on the productive sectors , reducing dependence and ensuring the solvency of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, which face unfair and destructive competition in the single market. These demands call for measures that the EU does not seem willing to adopt. They also call for the EU to face and reject constraints imposed by the EU, especially those associated with the euro. The significant strengthening of the EU budget that would be necessary, ensuring its redistributive function and the objective of effective economic and social cohesion, does not seem realistically achievable in the current context. The Recovery Plan suggested by the European Commission, which has yet to be implemented, risks seeing its resources primarily concentrated in the major European powers, which are already the biggest beneficiaries of integration, and in the large economic groups of these powers. In this context, the recovery of sovereignty instruments, particularly at economic and monetary level, is a structural necessity.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. Citizens and businesses have been asking us for answers for weeks now to deal with the greatest economic and social crisis facing our continent since the post-war period. We need innovative resources and instruments for an MFF and a recovery fund that preserve and relaunch the European economic, productive and social fabric: non-grant resources and non-loans, more simplification and less bureaucracy for our businesses, protection and relaunch of the internal market, and it is certainly a good thing that this Parliament recognises this. I regret, however, that, at the same time, we continue to be intransigent on many proposals, such as the green deal, or discuss new corporate taxes in order to raise resources for the new Community budget. The challenges we face in the coming months are without appeal, the situation we are experiencing is extraordinary, it is time for concrete and real ideas and proposals, not for persevering in ideological battles that will take the EU further and further away from its citizens and closer to the abyss.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: Writing. – The next MED will play a key role in boosting our economies after the crisis. I am asking the Commission to ensure that funding can be properly sourced from both the Recovery Fund and the seven-year budget. Crisis management should strive for the principle of geographical balance. Both instruments should strengthen EU convergence and create adequate opportunities for all Member States, whether members of the eurozone or non-euro zone. The instruments set up to combat a serious economic downturn must be designed and implemented in such a way as to provide real assistance not only to the Western and Southern Member States, but also to the Eastern Member States. Although the virus later reached cohesion countries, the latter are more vulnerable and therefore no new instrument can undersking cohesion policy. The recovery fund allocation key should be fair and equitable and should not contain any moral risk.  I am asking the Commission not to reward irresponsibility or poor performance. In order to avoid irresponsible farmers, such as Member States with higher debt levels or deficits, being rewarded for being unprepared for the crisis or being mishandled. In allocating recovery fund resources, previous good economic or crisis management performance should not result in financial disadvantage. Efforts should be made to ensure that all Member States receive assistance according to their needs and merits.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: Writing. – From this Europarlament meeting, we must send a clear call to the EU institutions, as well as to all Member States, to the swift adoption of an ambitious Recovery Plan for the European economy, sinking as a result of the months-long corona crisis. Only if all the EU institutions and all the Member States act quickly and courageously will we be able to meet the expectations of citizens disappointed by the EU's initial slow response at the beginning of the crisis. Since then, although the situation has improved and the Union's efforts to help combat the corona crisis can no longer be denied by anyone, there is still much to correct and, even on the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration, it must be shown that the EU can respond effectively even as the economy gets started. By the end of May, the European Commission should present an ambitious recovery plan, which, in the form of grants but also loans, will be able to help those states and regions most affected by the crisis and those sectors that proved to be the most vulnerable at the beginning of the crisis. In this plan, no affected region can be left behind, and aid must reach those most in need, to employees who have lost their jobs and thus to incomes, but also to entrepreneurs and sole traders who have fallen into debt because of the crisis. We must use economic recovery as a matter of priority to financially support economic activities contributing to our climate objectives.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. – I welcome the European Council meeting of 23 April 2020 that endorsed the roadmap towards lifting COVID-19 containment measures and a joint Roadmap for Recovery. The meeting also discussed important safety nets for workers and businesses. The European Commission has announced it will table a revised proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the years 2021-2027, together with a recovery instrument targeted at the effects of the COVID-19 crisis. I support the European Parliament’s call for a strong recovery plan commensurate with the size of the challenge we face, financed by recovery bonds guaranteed by the EU budget, and for an ambitious new MFF that both reflects the measures needed to address the crisis and the political priorities of the new Commission. As the resolution notes, the recovery plan and the new MFF must be aligned in structure and objectives. However, I do not support the resolution’s suggestions for EU own resources that would infringe on Irish tax sovereignty.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: in writing. – The EP's distance operating model does not allow it to intervene in plenary; I'm going to have to do it in writing. The EP has been united since the beginning of the MFF debate: we want a robust and timely MFF. We wanted it before, and now it's the only way to build a European response to the crisis. This is what Europeans expect; We can only say that the EU protects citizens if at times like the ones we go through we have answers to the challenges of people, businesses and employment, member states. The new MFF, which will be supported by adding the Recovery Fund, will have to: increase support for cohesion and cap, research, innovation and investment; re-re-emstocking the Internal Market with strategic investment in key industries, EU strategic value chains, which compensates Member States for spending on saving lives, jobs and protecting the standard of living of families; to make the EU more resilient in the global context, in a commitment to "de facto solidarity", i.e. pooling responsibilities and commitments. With increased own resources. Finally, under no circumstances, whatever the mechanisms to be proposed, we will accept a reduction in the ep's democratic powers or the strengthening of intergovernmental drift.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. – In a joint resolution, the EPP, S&D, Renew, Green and ECR Political Groups call for the ep's full involvement in the design, adoption and implementation of the EU recovery plan. They also stress that this recovery plan, to be presented by the EC, should not be financed to the detriment of the Multiannual Financial Framework or compromised its long-term priorities. The MFF should be consistent and should not be compromised by the need for a recovery plan. Parliament's consent may be at risk if there is no agreement on the EU's own resources and this is not taken into account in the architecture of the new Recovery Fund. This fund should be managed by the EC and financed by long-term obligations guaranteed by the EU budget which, to this end, should be strengthened. It is also important that member states do not impose additional burdens, and to reach the Member States most affected by the COVID-19 outbreak and in the form of direct grants or support, which is the main component of a general recovery package. Only in this way can we have a europe of solidarity, ready to help the countries in greatest difficulties, on the basis of the principle that no Member States can emerge from this crisis in isolation. Because I advocate the issue of joint debt, in this case the EC, and direct support to the Member States, which should preferably be in the form of subsidies and which do not represent additional public debt, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Dan-Ştefan MOTREANU
text: in writing. – Seventy years after the Schuman Declaration, the European Union faces its most serious socio—economic challenge, provoked by COVID-19. The EU’s GDP is expected to contract by 7.4%, our companies are facing risks of bankruptcy, while our citizens express fears for their future. Our collective response to this crisis will determine our people’s trust in the future of our common project. Accordingly, I underline the importance of reaching an institutional agreement in due time on the next Multiannual Financial Framework and Recovery Plan, in order to send a clear and firm message that the European Union is capable of delivering in these critical moments and of respecting its political commitments. I find it essential that the European Parliament, as the sole EU institution with members directly and democratically elected by EU citizens, play an active role in the shaping, adoption and implementation of the Recovery Fund, and I express my full disapproval of any European recovery strategy set outside the Community procedure. At the same time, allow me to reiterate Parliament’s resolutions to reform EU own resources system through the introduction of common consolidated corporate tax base, digital services taxation, a financial transaction tax, emissions trading scheme contributions, a tax on plastics and a carbon border adjustment mechanism.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The future MFF has to offer Europe a strong perspective for its recovery but also important commitments in terms of the type of economy and society we want to build for the future. The upcoming changes presumed to happen have been accelerated by the current COVID—19 crisis, and we need more than ever to try to make Europe a leading force of what will be the next technological revolutions. In this regard, we need an ambitious European budget and we need it now. We need the Member States to allocate more in order to do more things together in everyone’s interest. We need also fresh and fair own resources at EU level that protect our standards but also generate new funds for our objectives. Allocating EUR 2 trillion for the recovery plan can be a strong starting point. We need to allocate grants to those that most need it in order to create jobs and ensure the protection of our social standards. But what we have to make sure is that all these opportunities will be available to all Member States. The next budget can be a blueprint for the future we want to build. The new MFF must change Europe, or the EU may no more survive it.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union needs a robust economic recovery plan in response to the crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The crisis has caused a serious strain on social and health systems in the Member States. It concerns in particular vulnerable groups, which exacerbates inequalities and increases poverty and unemployment. EU GDP is forecast to decline by 7.4% in the coming months. I therefore agree that the reformed MFF and the European recovery strategy should be based on the principles of economic cohesion, social dialogue and transformation towards a resilient, sustainable, socially just and competitive economy.  It is important to me that the reconstruction instrument announced by the EC does not create an additional burden on national budgets and supports immediate action. Support would be provided in the form of grants, loans and financial guarantees. Investments would be directed where there are the greatest needs and focused on the areas most affected by the crisis and the less well-off. In the short term, the aim would be to ensure the continuity of cohesion policy and to support the liquidity of SMEs, and in the long term to take into account the Green Deal and the digital strategy.  I believe that this is a good proposal to maintain jobs and rebuild tourism, infrastructure, agriculture, transport, health. I hope that, as a consequence, we will build an EU that is resilient to future crises.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – The Fund for Economic Recovery and Transformation should not be associated with an additional burden on national treasuries. It is clear that not all countries are equally affected by crises, and their financial potential is also not equivalent. The expected support must reach every person. We therefore need to help adapt to new conditions, restructure activities, ensure resilience to the challenges of the future, and create capable, fast-responsive health systems. We need to restructure our economy and not repeat the mistakes of the past. The crisis has shown that agriculture was able to provide food to the population only because, unlike in other sectors, we have not yet brought the agricultural industry to China or India. Strengthening our farmers must therefore become a priority and this must be a priority. Short food supply chains must become a reality, not a declaration, but a reality that allows local produce to reach consumers' homes. At the same time, we need to review our strategies to ensure that imported food from third countries meets our safety and production standards at all stages of product production, from cultivation to the final product that has been placed on the market. This will create fair conditions for farmers to compete.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. – EU funding must also be involved in helping European economies, which poses a major challenge for the union's updated multiannual financial framework. Unfortunately, the majority of Parliament is pushing for some problematic points, which I have been opposed to for a long time. These include, in particular, new own financial resources, including new taxes. The Recovery Fund is to be financed in addition to existing IFF programmes without first seeking savings. We need spending reform within the IFF, with an emphasis on greater efficiency and prioritisation of truly pro-growth, value-added programmes for the future, such as Horizon or the space programme. The recovery should then be focused primarily on digitalisation, and I have repeatedly expressed my scepticism about continuing under the Green Plan.

name: László TRÓCSÁNYI
text: Writing. – These are the days when we commemorated the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration and the first steps of European edifyment. In the meantime, however, we must not forget that the declaration not only had a unifying effect, but also caused a rupture in the idea of Europe from the outset. It has sorely rejected the seeds of conflict between a transnational-inspired Europe that merges nations and a Europe that elevates strong and independent nations.  The 70-year-old European edifyment, which is in the age of federalism, is plagued by a series of crises. It is the first time a Member State has lost a Member State following the proliferation of terrorist attacks and the immigration crisis. And during the current epidemic, he is facing the biggest shock in his history.  The EU institutions have failed in recognising and predicting crises. They were unprepared and, by leaving the Member States defenceless, questioned the meaning of their existence. Just as 70 years ago, Europe needs renewal and fresh momentum, but above all soul.  If the idea of Europe continues to be caught up in ideologies, the political and economic weight of European nations will diminish in the new century. Millennial European nations do not need to be recreateed. Therefore, instead of the "ever closer union" that has become self-serving, we need an alliance that will make our nations stronger and more competitive in the world. The anniversary and the Conference on the Future of Europe are an opportunity for spiritual renewal.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: Writing. – The form of the multiannual financial framework has always divided – not only Parliament, but also national governments in the Council. In this respect, the coronavirus crisis has at least set a common goal, having swept away many earlier challenges and created new, larger and more serious ones. In many economic sectors, the consequences of shutdown are already manifesting themselves – and may be worse, economists say. It all depends on how quickly we can rebuild the European economy. It is essential to make the Recovery Fund a top priority and restore confidence in the European project, which has been severely damaged in some Member States during the crisis. The EU must be on hand to help Member States restart economies, free up their hands to comply with regulations, and allow them to focus on the most damaged sectors. On the other hand, in order to avoid budgetary irresponsibility, pre-crisis ambitions must give priority to tackling immediately burning and urgent problems. In the Green Deal field, for example, it is the fight against a catastrophic drought, not the CO2 reduction race, for which the EU will now have no partners in the world. I believe that we will be able to get Europe back on its feet, and with that we will return the luxury of different priorities.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Writing. – Negotiations on a new multiannual financial framework, a large EU budget, for 2021-2027 are now in a completely different situation compared to a few months ago. It is, of course, right that the new budgetary framework must take into account the effects and consequences of the coronavirus pandemic. We need a budget that helps the Member States, is flexible and allows money to be used without unnecessary red tape. However, we need a budget that is not financed on debt and does not burden Member States with excessive redistribution without much benefit. Unfortunately, the European Parliament's proposal under debate does not meet these conditions. First of all, there is an effort to create new Euro-servants for which the Union as a whole will be responsible, punishing states that have managed responsibly and created reserves for worse times, and rewarding states that have inconceivably spent. Proposals to create new Euro-taxes, be they financial transactions, digital services, plastic products or emissions, will lead to less tax collection at national level and worsen the position of nation states to finance services and investment for their citizens. Finally, the stubborn insistence on astronomical spending on the New Green Deal policy will do us much more damage in budget and economics than the current pandemic. I must therefore reject this proposal from the European Parliament, because it will not help citizens and will only lead to problems in the future.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Parliament adopted in its previous plenary a resolution which paved the way for the European Union to initiate a more coordinated and supportive process in response to the pheamic crisis and its health, economic and social impacts. The time has come to move to a robust achievement. The resolution tabled in this Plenary by most political groups sets out priority lines that should be taken into account by the European Commission in formulating its proposal for a Multiannual Financing Plan 2021/2027, strengthening own resources in its funding and defining a robust recovery and transformation plan. They should also be taken into account when assessing the proposal, when presented, by the European Council. The priority of the European response has to be to save people. This is the decisive step in keeping the social fabric sustainable and recovering businesses and the economy. The European Parliament's proposal is balanced, viable and could benefit all member states and their citizens. I hope that the vote on the resolution will be significantly favourable and that the action induced will be up to the urgency and necessity.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We shall now proceed to the second voting time. We shall proceed to the vote on the first block of amendments to the discharge resolutions and also to the final vote on the objection under Rule 112 on genetically modified soya. The votes will take place using the same procedure as at the first voting time. The second voting time will be open from 8.00 p.m. to 9.15 p.m. The vote will be open shortly.  You have until 9.15 p.m. to vote. The results of this second round will be announced tomorrow at the opening of the plenary session at 9.00 a.m.
